warmers and crochet cast-on badger scarf are worked sideways casting standard bind-off on stitches according to the length of the garter stitch in flat k all sts garment and knitting in flat in garter stitch knit all stitches on both sides to the desired width helpful links you will start by casting on the required crochet cast on number of stitches using the crochet cast-on magic knot method this method is very easy and very mattress stitch 8 40 handy especially for the badger scarf where you need to cast on quite a few stitches at the beginning abbreviations you will work in flat to the required width and k = knit loosely bindoff all stitches st s = stitch es sl = slip for the badger wrist warmers you will then kw = knitwise proceed to sewing the cast-on and bind-off wyib = with yarn in back edges together using a tapestry needle knitting pattern by milena pauliina milena juhola ©copyright @milenapauliina 3 2023 this pattern is for personal use only the pattern is not to #badgerset be copied sold or redistributed neither is the sale of garments made from this pattern allowed begin here your notes badger wrist warmers my tips start by taking some measurements for this you will need a soft tape measure i recommend using cm s for your measurements to get the most accurate results using your hand as a guide measure how long you want your wrist warmers to be when you have decided on the length multiply that with the 1 cm stitch gauge you calculated earlier example you want your wrist warmers to be 19 cm long 19 x 2 5 = 47 5 if you end up with a decimal number round this to the nearest full number 48 you will need to cast-on 48 stitches for your wrist warmers to make them approximately 19 cm long write down the amount of stitches you need to cast-on for the wrist warmers to fit properly you will want to add 15 % of negative ease to the finished width wrap the tape measure around the palm of your hand take that measurement and multiply it with 0 85 example the circumference of your palm is 18 cm 18 x 0 85 = 15 3 ~ 15 cm you will need to work 15 cm in width before binding off the last measurement you need is for the thumb again using the tape measure and your hand as a guide measure the length from the bottom of the thumb where your thumb and index finger form a v to where your thumb meets your wrist this measurement will tell you how long of a gap to leave for the thumb you now have your measurements and you are ready to start knitting
